Well the chain weight is likely to hit first right? The extra weight of the chain pulling on the right not only trumps wind resistance but the rotation of the chain over itself also transfers a small amount of energy into the weight as rotation, sending it downward slightly faster, especially at the second half of the fall. Anything tied to a loose wire will reach its destination exponentially faster as it gets close to the end of the line. Like popping a bull whip, the force of the rope pulling on itself is what causes the massive speedup.

There is a simple logic to answer this. Consider this: as the chain falls, more and more of it comes to a stop as it reaches the lower most point of the fold of the chain. Where is the kinetic energy of the stopped chain going? If the chain was frictionless, then this energy is transferred to the still moving section of the chain, this increasing its speed further. This implies that the weight attached to the chain will fall first.

As the chain weight drops the chain goes from part of the fbd object to a stationary, separate tension. However the energy of the stopping chain must be conserved, so it is transferred to the falling object and remaining chain. As the amount of falling chain decreases the transferred energy of the chain becomes a larger proportion to the remaining accelerating (falling) mass and the rate of acceleration is increasing. So (m/s^3?) The greater the mass of the chain per second (with constant mass) the greater the proportion of decelerating (stopping mass) will be to the remaining mass and the final acceleration will be greater as a result.
F=ma
Ft= (Mass per second)(deceleration)

I had trouble grasping how this "whipping" happens, until I thought of it this way:

Imagine one chain link right at the bottom of the falling chain, in a horizontal position, as it connects the fixed and the falling parts of the rest of the chain. We know the fixed part should play no role (it's hanging by the railing), and the falling part should play no role (it's free-falling along with the weight) - but that one link at the bottom (also free falling so far) is just being arrested at it's "fixed part" end; due to its inertia, that one link obviously resist suddenly being stopped and thus pulls on both its ends - the "fixed part" just gets slightly tensioned, but the "falling part" starts pulling down on the weight.

This also seems to imply that the only difference in the fall of the two weights is caused by a single chain link at a time, which should lead to a chain with larger, heavier links having a larger influence on the weight than a chain with small, light links. Then again, I might be wrong on that...

another explanation:

system 1: weight
system 2: weight+chain
PE: potential energy
KE: kinetic energy

system 2 has larger initial PE (because the chain has positive PE)

neglecting losses; just before the impact, all initial PE should be transformed to KE. at that instant in time, only the weight is moving in both of the systems (ignore lateral velocity).

since system 2 had more PE to begin with, it should have more KE in the end. larger KE means larger velocity, hence the smaller flight time.
